evidence: This is the technology used in nearly all current CT scanners.
Instead of summing all energies together, photon-counting detectors measure each incoming photon individually and record its energy.
A variation of this is dual-energy imaging, where two different energy spectra are used to give some limited energy discrimination.
That means they can separate photons into different energy bins, giving us spectral information.
With this approach, we can do material decomposition, K-edge imaging, and molecular-level X-ray imaging.
That gives us grayscale images - the kind you are familiar with in clinical CT.
energy-integrating detectors are the current standard
they promise higher resolution, lower dose, and much richer information content
Instead of summing all energies together, photon-counting detectors measure each incoming photon individually and record its energy.

used in nearly all current CT scanners. They simply collect all the incoming photons and integrate their total energy. Whether a photon has high energy or low energy, the detector just sums them up. That gives us grayscale images - the kind you are familiar with in clinical CT. A variation of this is dual-energy imaging, where two different energy spectra are used to give some limited energy discrimination. Dual-energy CT is already widely applied, for example, to distinguish iodine contrast from calcium.
